skill.name: git-commit-helper
skill.description: Generate descriptive commit messages by analyzing git diffs. Use when the user asks for help writing commit messages or reviewing staged changes.
skill.summary: Generate descriptive commit messages by analyzing git diffs. Use when the user asks for help writing...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing only guidance for writing git commit messages. The static scanner produced false positives: it misidentified English words like 'analyze' and 'conventional' as cryptographic terms, misidentified a content verification hash as C2 malware indicators, and flagged git command examples as external command execution. No executable code, network operations, or malicious patterns exist. The skill is purely informational.

content.value_statement: Writing clear commit messages is difficult. This skill analyzes git diffs and generates well-structured commit messages following conventional commits format, making your commit history readable and maintainable.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes git diffs to understand code changes
Suggests appropriate commit types (feat, fix, docs, refactor, test, chore)
Identifies scopes for frontend, backend, and infrastructure changes
limitations: Does not execute git commands directly - provides guidance for users
Does not amend or push commits automatically
Does not integrate with external git hosting services
Requires user to run git commands and provide diff output

use_cases.title: Quick commit messages
use_cases.description: Generate clear, consistent commit messages for daily development work without memorizing conventions.

use_cases.title: Enforce commit standards
use_cases.description: Help team members write standardized commit messages that work well with automated changelog tools.

use_cases.title: Maintain clean history
use_cases.description: Create meaningful commit histories that make it easier to understand project evolution and write release notes.

prompt_templates.title: Basic commit
prompt_templates.prompt:
Help me write a commit message for these staged changes:

git diff --staged output here

Use conventional commits format with appropriate type and scope.

prompt_templates.title: Feature commit
prompt_templates.prompt:
I am adding a new feature. Analyze my staged changes and create a conventional commit message:

[git diff --staged output]

Include the type, scope, and a clear description in the summary line.

prompt_templates.title: Breaking change
prompt_templates.prompt:
My changes include breaking changes. Generate a conventional commit message that clearly indicates this:

[git diff --staged output]

Use the ! notation and explain the breaking change in the footer.

prompt_templates.title: Complex refactor
prompt_templates.prompt:
I have refactored multiple files. Analyze all the staged changes and create a single commit message that captures the overall refactoring purpose:

[git diff --staged output]

Include a summary and body that explains the refactoring rationale.

output_examples.input: Generate a commit message for these staged changes that add user authentication with JWT tokens
output: Implement user login with JWT-based authentication:
- Add login endpoint with token generation
- Add refresh token support for session management
BREAKING CHANGE: Auth service now requires config object with secret key

best_practices: Use imperative mood in summary line (add, fix, refactor not added, fixed, refactored)
Keep summary under 50 characters and explain changes in body when needed
Reference issue numbers and clearly mark breaking changes with BREAKING CHANGE footer
anti_patterns: Using vague messages like 'update', 'fix stuff', or 'misc changes'
Including technical implementation details in the summary line
Mixing unrelated changes into a single commit (non-atomic commits)

faq.question: What AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude Code and Claude. It provides guidance for generating commit messages through natural conversation.

faq.question: What is the character limit for commit summaries?
faq.answer: Keep commit summaries under 50 characters. This is a soft convention to ensure readability in git log and GitHub interfaces.

faq.question: Does this integrate with git hosting platforms?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides guidance and message suggestions. Users must run git commands and commit changes themselves.

faq.question: Is my code or repository data sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No. This is a local guidance skill. Git diff output is analyzed locally within your conversation without being sent to external services.

faq.question: Why are my generated messages rejected by my team?
faq.answer: Check that you are using the correct type (feat/fix/docs/style/refactor/test/chore), appropriate scope, and following your team's commit message conventions.

faq.question: How is this different from git commit templates?
faq.answer: Git commit templates set a starting point for messages. This skill actively analyzes your actual code changes and generates specific, contextual commit messages.
